Posts.Content: CBANN:  I'm answering you just because I want you to know people are reading and listening.  You'll probably get a lot of answers.  From what I think I know, radial scarring is basically a benign hyperplasia disease of the breast..  In itself it is not cancer.  However, it can be linked to cancer.  I'd make sure you get adequate follow up to rule out anything else.  If they're telling you that your radial scarring is definitely not linked to cancer, it's possible that hormonal fluctuations could have caused it.  I'm sure other things could cause it as well.  Like I said, i'm no expert on this, but just trying to give you a bit of comfort.  Not knowing and 2nd guessing everything is THE PITS!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Radial scars

Posts.Content: Hi Rgonza:  My RT Oncologist told me to take Calcium and D as well.  My surgeon told me he wants me on an all purpose vitamin - in my case Centrum Silver.  The Centrum has the C and boron along with tons of other things, so I would assume that what you got should be fine.  Doesn't hurt to call and ask the office anyhow.  Mira
Posts.Title: Letrozol and vitamins

Posts.Content: Hey Ronstar: You ask a difficult question as each of us will handle things in our own unique way.  Personally, I put everything out front with a positive and frank attitude.  But that's just me.  I too am in the Cosmetology industry and taught it for 15 years, so I can relate to your field at least.  It sounds like you're much further down this odious path we've taken, but I offer you this.  You're in a personal service industry and you know as well as I do that either students or clients tend to spill their guts to their stylists and/or teachers.  You've been given a very unique opportunity to be able to "connect" to others going through the emotional roller coasters of breast cancer.  Ask yourself what you would want an employee to do and follow your instinct.  Good for you on going back to work!  One day I might be doing the same!  Hugs, Mira Oh!  Wanted to add that I got sent to teach a class in Miami one time.  No one spoke English.  I spoke no Spanish.  You KNOW your field.  You can teach with words or by demonstration.  You're going to do GREAT!~
Posts.Title: Hand holding and advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi xmm2onex:  I'm quite a bit older than you and certainly didn't have the worries that you have with a little one at your feet, but the way you're feeling right now is perfectly normal.  I don't care what age you are, the initial steps are terrifying and so full of uncertainty and guessing.  You're not alone and there are lots and lots of people on here that are close to your situation.  You'll have questions that you need to write down and take to the Dr. with you.  Read a lot of the stories on here and you'll get some fabulous pointers.  I've found that the unknown and guessing are far worse than the actual procedures you go through.  I'm sure someone else will be along shortly to give you some good information and directions, but I wanted you to know that my heart goes out to you and I'm sending a gentle hug from across the pond.  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: New to this site and very worried!

Posts.Content: Hi NicNic: You very eloquently described the roller coaster of emotions that I think most of us have or were experiencing.  My BC was differently diagnosed, but those horrible fears of it having spread to the rest of my body were identical.  A leg hurts and you think it's in your leg.  A dizzy spell and you fear it's gone to your brain.  Awful feelings and there doesn't seem to be any way to control them.  But you will.  You'll get through this stage of terror and move on to other stages.  You've already had some very good advice on here, and I don't want to just repeat it, but want you to know that you're so very normal in your reaction thus far.  Hold on to the thought that your lymph nodes are your filters to keep it from spreading.  Take a day at a time and do what ever you can to feel calmness.  I do meditation with world music.  This community has been a bulwark for me to keep sane.  Rant and weep if you will and there will always be someone to give you a gentle cyber hug.  We'll also celebrate your victories with you.  And you're going to have victories!  One day at a time sweet girl.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - feel like I'm living a nightmare

Posts.Content: Hey Nikki: It's me again just coming along to say "Good job!"  Distractions and lovely friends like the one you describe are so beneficial.  I knew you'd have a ton of support coming from here and just having a few people who really understand is so very beneficial.  You don't feel quite so alone in the abyss when you know others are walking the same road.  I'm about to take my next big step into radiation on August 21st and there are still lots of questions and unknowns,  but it's so wonderful to be able to come on here and voice worries and have someone give you their insights.  Everything from types of radiation, to personal experiences, to best creams and best bras and good suggestions on the types of questions to ask.  I wrote down everything I thought I needed to know and took a notebook with me to my pre-op.  My surgeon laughed and said, "I see you've been doing your homework.  What questions do you have for me?"  And he sat down and answered them all.  What a man!  When I said education is knowledge I meant beneficial education.  Dr. Google will scare the bejeebers out of you, so look at this site and other reputable cancer sites when you need to research things.  And above all do more fun things like you did with your friend.   You've less than a week now till you're going to be able to mark off another "completed" box on your list of things you have to do.  We'll be here for you.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - feel like I'm living a nightmare

Posts.Content: Oh Mazza, if they have a bell, do ring it.  It's not just for you.  It gives everyone hope and a bit of joy knowing that there's a light at the end of the tunnel.  There were some tiny ones in my hospital who were so very excited when I rang my bell.  Keep drinking and slathering, you're almost there!  Just so you know, don't quit the creams for a month after you're done.  I had no blistering till a week after my last zap.  And even then it wasn't bad.  A bit itchy and they tended to weep as they popped, but pretty much like a sunburn blister.  LOLOL  I used cornstarch on them to stop the weeping and it felt heavenly!  However, it adhered to the blister so strongly that it made tiny pin prick size white scabs on me for a couple of days.  When I first saw them I was watching TV and noticed tiny blue lights glowing out of my chest.  TV was reflecting off the cornstarch!  Good luck!  Mira
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ December Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Awww Mazza, I'm so happy for you.  Tomorrow is probably going to be a bit teary with all the bell ringing, but they will be tears of joy and hope!  You're so close to the end now and I can't say how happy I am.  Please don't expect to jump right back into "normal" what ever that may be.  Your skin is fragile now and you need to be very gentle with it.  The tiredness lifts slowly and soon you'll be up to more and more exertions.  Good Job!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ December Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Deirdre: I'm not doing chemo but will be doing radiation soon.  I'm replying here only because I'm prone to shingles outbreaks.  In very odd places at times.  I've found that very cool water is one of the best things to stop the pain.  I actually do ice packs sometimes.  When mine were originally diagnosed they did it with a scraping of the affected tissue.  Not sure if a blood test would turn them up or not, but it sure wouldn't hurt to ask.  When I feel mine beginning to flare up I pull out the ice as soon as possible.  It seems to accelerate the life cycle of the nasty little buggers.  Hope that was helpful.  Mira
Posts.Title: Shingles?

Posts.Content: Hi Jillybean21:  I'm adding another welcome and sending lots of positive energy to you!  I'm happy that your cancer was found early on and they're moving forward quickly to get it taken care of!  I live in the States and the ladies on this site have been my salvation.  There's always someone here to help assure you that you're not having unusual feelings, to give advice, to offer a heads up on questions you should be asking your team and just to offer a shoulder to lean on.  We all need that from time to time.  Do lots of reading on here and write down any and everything you don't quite understand to ask your Doctor.  I took a whole notebook page full of questions to mine and he was delighted with my "homework".  What day is your surgery?   Welcome again, and I'll send you a cyber hug without the picture.  I haven't quite figured that one out yet.  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recently been diagnosed, looking for support through my journey.

Posts.Content: Good Morning Mazza!  Good for you on deciding to ring your bell!  Oh I wish you could have seen those little girls and boys with their little  bald heads clapping excitedly for me.  Oh my gosh I just cried.   I'll tell you, I did Aloe and Eucerin Cream for my rads, and it worked just fine.  Of course you want to follow the directions of what ever your team tells you, but if they don't give specific directions, you can only try to be as proactive as possible.  The radiation continues to work for some time after you're done, so don't quit applying the creams liberally.  In fact, I'm still using the cream liberally almost 2.5 months out.  My Letrozole tends to dry the skin as it depletes or stops Estrogen production.  I've found CeraVe to really help with the dryness.   The hardness you're feeling is probably just as you team said.  The RT is making the scar tissue harden.  After you're all done with RT, one of your BC team may show you how to do scar shredding.  That and manual lymph drainage are where I am now.  But I feel good.  Really good.   LOL AND if you do happen to blister a little, ask them about the cornstarch.  I was done, so just used it and it did feel good and stop the itching and weeping!  But not to worry if you see the blue dots.  It's just the TV reflection!   xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ December Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hello again Jillybean!  (by the way, I love your screen name!)  I'm so glad you've found a bit of comfort from being here!  I know I sure did.  I also had a lumpectomy and after the post operative biopsy they upgraded me from a stage I grade 3 to a stage IIA.  Not a whole lot of difference in my case - the upgrade was only due to the size of the tumor they removed.  It was quite a bit larger than they had expected.  Anyhow, this is not a horror story.  My Oncotype test (which they did during the surgical biopsy) placed me in a moderate risk range for re-occurrence.  My oncologist and I had already discussed that if that test had come back with a high score I would do chemo and then radiation.  If it was moderate or low I would only do radiation.  Yay on the moderate score, so I started radiation and tomorrow I get to ring the bell as I finish my treatments.  Just so you know, I followed all the advice I got on here with my Dr's nod and have had no burning or soreness at all from radiation.  I've been taking Letrozole for 4 months and have no side effects.  My point in this is that we're all different and may experience different things, but there's always someone out there who has been or is going or will be going through exactly what you are experiencing.  You can turn to them for support, and one day you will become the support for another soul beginning this journey!  As has been said, take one step at a time and focus on what happens next.  I like to have a bit of an understanding of what might come after the next, but digging deeper into it can wait till the next step is done.  Just my way of coping.   I'll be thinking of you on Tuesday!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recently been diagnosed, looking for support through my journey.

Posts.Content: Congratulations Saxophone lou!!  I'm so happy for you and you're an inspiration!  Hugs from across the water!  Mira
Posts.Title: Job done

Posts.Content: Good Morning Frances! I hope you can get your R1 R2 cream, but please don't get too upset if you can't.  I'm in the States and it's simply not available here so I used Aloe for cooling and Eucerin Calming Cream for moisturizing.  4 times a day.  What I didn't realize was that my whole chest wall was being radiated and I wasn't as thorough in putting the cream all the way up to my collar bone.  I did go under the arm and over to the opposite breast with it.  After 19 sessions of RT the only area to blister was above the breast where I had not been particularly careful to moisturize.  Even my blisters weren't too bad.  They burned and itched some, but 3 days later are now little white freckles.  Kind of ugly, but this too shall pass.  My RT oncologist suggested chamomile creams post radiation.  My physical therapist suggested shea butter post RT.  I chose the shea butter and it's been heavenly!  Now to get the lymphedema under control!   Don't forget to drink lots and lots of water once you start your RT!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Jacks:  I'm sorry your diagnosis wasn't a bit better, but good for you on taking the bull by the horns and getting the information you need sooner rather than later!  You're definitely treatable and you need to keep that in the front of your thoughts.   My cancer was also invasive ductal carcinoma, though it was a grade  II A.  I had a lumpectomy done and am very glad I did even though it's not been a walk in the park.  When they did the lumpectomy they sent off the sentinel lymph node and portions of the tumor for the oncotype testing.  Doing the test was another good move for me as it helped to determine if I would be better off having chemo or not.  Thank goodness I didn't have to have it, but I was gearing myself up for it and getting myself ready. As far as researching, yes, you can find all sorts of information on the web.  And some of it's good information, but more often it's worst case scenarios or out of date information.  My suggestion to you is to use the MacMillan search bars and dig your information out that way.  You'll at least hear real life stories from people walking in the same shoes you've been given.  And you'll hear both positives and negatives.  Get your facts first and then if you want to visit Dr. Google, you can do so armored with facts.  It's all a bit overwhelming unless you're able to look at only a piece at a time.   I wish I could give you a good back rub.  I understand your sense of overwhelming sadness.  I'm hoping by the time you read this you'll be on one of the up swings of our roller coaster ride.  I've never liked roller coasters particularly well.  But yes, you're very correct.  The brain runs riot on you.  You over think, over worry and over imagine all sorts of things.  I know you've heard this, but a repeat won't hurt.  Do things that are special to you.  Try to have a little fun.   You can't rush time and the next step in your journey may seem very far off, but I assure you that it will be on top of you before you know it.  Since I can't offer you a nice relaxing massage, I'm sending another gentle, virtual hug.  Keep me posted!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis before biopsy results

Posts.Content: Ah Jacks, I'm not the best at describing Stages and grades and sure don't want to alarm you any more than you already are.  I was told initially that I was Stage I grade 3.  Which pretty much means they caught it fairly early, but the grade 3 indicated that it was pretty large.  When they actually did the lumpectomy the tumor was larger than they had originally thought (3.5 cm) so they upgraded me to Stage II.  As far as I can tell when you're in stage II it's either an A or B grade vs the 1, 2, 3 they use in Stage I.  That probably made no sense at all.  Don't fuss about it till you know.  You're not going to change anything and you'll just make yourself sick worrying and alarming yourself.  I think you did a brilliant thing spending time with your granddaughter who brings a smile to your face and heart.  Sheesh - even though it cost you a bit to have that virtual meal.  That was hilarious!  Embrace times like that and when you're testing or preparing for the next step bring it to mind.  I'll tell you some silly things I did.  I had to have a contrast MRI done.  That was an odd experience.  I burst out laughing when I saw the position they were going to make me lie in.  Pretended I was a mermaid for about 15 minutes.  I told my oncologist about that and she thought it was a wonderful thing.  Attitude is everything.  And yes sometimes the emotions go wonky, but over all try to stay focused and ready for the next step.  I promise it will go faster than you think.  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis before biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi Jacks77: I'm so sorry you're beginning this horrible journey.  The procedures they'll do (when you find out what your specific recommendations are) are mostly hurdles to jump and when you know what they are you just get on with it.  I'm not saying you won't be apprehensive leading up to them, but it's amazing how strong we can be when we have to.  I think the hardest part of any of it is the waiting and uncertainly.  Also the second guessing.  Our minds take us to levels that our bodies haven't even considered most of the time.  So right now you're in the waiting game and my heart goes out to you.  You found a wonderful place to vent and ask questions.  We can be your cheerleaders, you can vent or you can cry on shoulders and someone will at least give you a hug and/or encouragement.  So I'm sending you a big hug!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis before biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi Jacks:  I'm going to send you a friend request and if you want just rant or ask questions but don't want to put it out for everyone, you're more than welcome to do so.  So far your "journey" sounds a lot like mine was.  I found my lump the end of March, had Mammo early April followed by ultrasound and biopsy.  On my birthday they called to give me the biopsy results.  Well Happy Birthday Me!  2 weeks later I was in for surgery.  At that point I knew I was ER+ but not sure about the HER portion yet either.  What a mix of emotions!  Up and down and round in circles my head went  I made a list of everything I heard people talking about on here and didn't know the answers to in my own situation.  First post surgery appointment with my surgeon I took the whole notebook and a pen with me and he was just marvelous in sitting down to answer any and everything I had thought to ask.  I had a few complications that most people don't have post surgery, so it wasn't until early August that he sent me on to my next leg of the journey which was Oncology.  Oncology discussed things with me and together we set the rest of my plan.  My oncotype test indicated that I didn't need chemo, so radiation was next.  RT isn't bad.  As long as you keep well hydrated and creamed you're good most of the time.  Now I'm done.  Return next week to surgeon for final time and hopefully will be released from him.  Of course I'm still on the hormone therapy (Letrozole) but am one of the truly blessed ones and have no side affects at all.  You're going to do just fine.  Sending a Saturday morning hug to you!  (It's 6 am here).  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis before biopsy results

Posts.Content: Good Morning Anna K: Welcome to the site that no one wants to join!  I say that with a chuckle, because of course you don't want to have to be researching and finding out about BC, but I can tell you that you've found the best place to stay up to date and informed.  I live in the States and am actually in 2 BC groups here, but they are not nearly as responsive or informative or friendly as this one.   You sound a lot like me in your attitude.  Just kind of grit your teeth and get on with it.  That was one of my major issues.  The getting on with it part.  It seems like there is so much waiting and guessing and wondering and sometimes panicking that you feel your life is out of control.  That's a portion of the roller coaster that London Lass referred to.  But hang on to this thought, You're going to have lots of good days and you'll have some upsetting ones as well.  During the waiting times use the wait to get yourself as well informed as possible about the who, what, where, why and when of everything connected with your your next step to keep yourself well informed and build an arsenal of questions.  I'm a Navy vet and I thought of it as "battle prep" time.  And now, post surgery and post RT I think I won the war.  Of course we'll be sending out surveillance teams to stay safe, but for me, the hardest part is done.  So here I am to offer a hand and to walk a distance with you.  You'll likely find others who are on a closer path and may develop some wonderful support buddies on here, but you have a whole group of us out here to be your cheerleaders as well as to be a shoulder when you need to cry. As far as your scans - they can serve 2 purposes.  One of course is to check for abnormalities elsewhere, and the other is to serve as a base line for future reference.  Both of the scans you mentioned are painless.  But they both provide you and your team with lots of information.   I'll be thinking of you lots this week and sending energy, peace and strength your way.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Hello and thank you for being there

Posts.Content: Hi Margo61: Trish gave you a very good rule of thumb.  It usually takes about 6 weeks to heal from surgery, though we're all a little different.  A caution I'll give to you is this.  Keep a very close eye on your incision.  Don't assume that discomfort is normal.  I really didn't know what the warning signs were and developed a pretty nasty infection post surgery - which put everything off till later.  Actually I had to have a 2nd surgery as well, though that one healed beautifully.  All in all from 1st surgery till RT began was 16 weeks.  But RT wasn't bad at all.  I found meeting all the other people and hearing their stories wonderful.  I made some lovely friends during RT.  Good Luck!  Mira
Posts.Title: My Treatment Plan

Posts.Content: You're quite welcome Anna K!  I'm delighted that something I said gave you a modicum of comfort.  I'm following you and MVI's journey through this.  I'm only a month past RT myself and it wasn't too bad at all.  You're hormone receptor positive and HER negative right?  Are you getting an oncotype test done?  I would encourage you to look into them at least.  It gives you a better idea of what the recurrence factor will be.  I didn't have to pay extra for mine, but our health care systems are different.  I think you said you will meet with your surgeon soon?  LOL  I had a notebook full of questions for mine and he was such a dear when he saw them.  He started laughing and said, "Ohhhh, so you have questions for me do you?"  And he sat himself down and answered every one of them.  It sounds like your team is every  bit as caring.  They're your troops and you're going to win this battle!  Keep in touch warrior!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Hello and thank you for being there

Posts.Content: Good for you!  I know you're relieved that it's finally "getting on".  I had a similar issue with healing and was frustrated that RT was taking what seemed to be forever to start.  I also had 19 treatments to do.  As I get ready to go in this morning I'm amazed at how quickly they've gone.  After today I'll have 3 more sessions and then I get to ring the bell!  Just so you know, start the aloe and your cream early and put it on frequently.  I'm at session 16/19 and have no burning at all.  Actually my breast is just slightly tanned.  For me, the worst thing is being tired.  I've tried really ramping up the water to help alleviate the tiredness, and maybe it's helped some.  Good luck!~  Mira
Posts.Title: My Treatment Plan

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy: I'm post menopausal and only been on Letrozole for about 5 months.  I was on the Femara brand and had no issues with it.  The pharmacy arbitrarily switched me to a generic and bad symptoms began cropping up rapidly.  I saw my Dr. and she said to quit the generic immediately.  Now she's going head to head with the pharmacy trying to get me back on to the Femara.  If pharmacy won't change she said that she would entirely change my meds.  I believe her first choice is going to be Exemestane which is a steroidal AI, but she did mention possibly putting me on Tamoxifen.  I told her that I thought Tamoxifen was just for pre-menopausal woman and she told me that it is usually prescribed for pre-menopausal, but also works for post-menopausal.  It's not quite as effective as Letrozole and Anastrozole, but it does work.  For now I'm on nothing until this battle between Oncologist and Pharmacy is determined, but I'm wondering if Exemestane might not be the way to go.  I'm reading that it causes less bone loss and irreversibly prevents the production of oestrogen even after coming off the drug.  The other 2 AI's will allow oestrogen to begin to be produced again.  Hope that was helpful.  Mira
Posts.Title: Should I be switched from tamoxifen to a aromatase inhibitor post...

Posts.Content: I didn't do chemo either, but I'm a licensed cosmetologist in the States.  As your hair starts to grow back it will itch.  You could try the Baby Shampoo, but it's a bit alkaline.  It will, however, "lift" the plaque scales of keratin that have formed on your scalp and allow freer exit for the new hair to emerge.  If you want to do a rinse with some slightly acid product, you could mix a bit of vinegar with water and do a final rinse.  It will get all residue off your scalp and also put the pH of your skin where it needs to be.  As always, if you're not completely done with your chemo, check with your team before doing anything new!   Mira
Posts.Title: Head itching

Posts.Content: Thanks for the welcome Leo Lady  Unfortunately I'm not going to be getting my time in for the next few days.  We go to "close" on the new house today and begin the actual move on Sunday.  By next Thursday I should be lapping the pond.  It's a lovely big pond - actually looks like a small lake and I'll certainly get some pictures to send.  LOL  Yes, we're still in FL and will do my best to bottle up some of our famous sunshine for you chilly gals!  Yesterday it hit 80 degrees here and was absolutely marvelous!  In the meantime till I join you all in our everyday strolls, I'll be your cheerleader.  Rah, rah you are the Champions!  Good job ladies!  xxoo Mira

Posts.Content: Oh my gosh!  I got it!  This bird is about 5 foot tall with a wing span well over 6 foot.  He/she visits our pond nearly every day

Posts.Content: Oooohhh!  I do like this thread.  Mind if I join ya'll?  For now I'm only getting about 7000 steps per day, but we're in the midst of moving to a new home in a little town.  Once all the moving is done, I'm aiming for 12000 steps a day.  I'll have a lovely "pond" to walk around.  When we get there, I'll send pictures!  I think I need the encouragement and accountability to get the lead out of the bottom side.  Thanks LL!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Morning Lovely Ladies: I'm still not taking official walks, but managed to get in 8000 steps yesterday as we packed up the outdoor equipment and moved a lot of the plants to an easier loading area.  It's rather sad to see everything looking rather barren.  We're taking a really big load to our new home today and hopefully will get the majority of the inside things tomorrow.  After that I'll do my best to post some pictures of our lovely new pond.  LOL  No worries for you ladies being able to identify sites from me!   I got a new generic Letrozole and have been on it for 3 days now.  Not much to gauge yet, but so far I don't seem to have any adverse reactions to it.  A bit of a headache.   I'm hoping that this thread and you beautiful cheerleaders out there will keep me focused and walking and maybe it will continue to keep the side effects low.  The last generic I tried was horrible.  BC - the unwanted gift that keeps on giving.  Much love ladies!  Walk in beauty.  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Thanks Karen:  I don't know what I'm doing wrong in trying to upload this file.  An IT I am not.  Anyhow, it was very pretty and I had some lovely sunsets and dawns as well.  Oh well.  It's either back to the old phone or not sharing.  Sorry.  I have my first mammogram and Ultra sound post surgery and RT later this week, and will be getting a lymphedema pump as well.  Talk about being spoiled!  Love to you all!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: What an incredibly beautiful tree!  I don't post a lot, but you guys are inspiring me to push myself physically.  Now If I don't get well over 10000 steps I'm a bit disgusted with myself.  Keep posting you're touching lives.  Oh!  Went for a revisit to RT onco and she said, "You look fantastic!  You've lost weight, your skin is in good condition (breast skin) and there's currently no sign of lymphedema!  Keep being proactive and I'll see you again in 6 months."  Yay!  Hugs to all, Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi What Happened:  I've tried all of that.  It does all that you said, and IF the pictures were actually uploaded to my computer it would work, but my new phone won't upload except to Google and it won't upload FROM Google to here.  Alas, you'll just have to take my word that the heron was lovely.  A beautiful big white one.  Being very lazy today after the terror of driving into Jacksonville for blood work in a horrendous storm at 5:30 in the morning.  When I got home I hit the sack.  I had cataract surgery several years ago and night driving is challenging because of glare.  Add to that torrential downpours and rush hour traffic on a busy freeway and Good Golly Molly!  Will get back on track tomorrow I think.  Hugs to all!  Mira

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies:  Not doing a lot of just straight walking, but surely getting plenty of steps in.  Yesterday I hit my record of 23500.  I did it while raking leaves, twigs, bagging them, mowing etc.  I'm counting it.  And boy was I one pooped puppy at the end of the day!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi everyone!  It's been quite a while since I've been on here and I do miss keeping up with all of you.  Our move has simply eaten up most of my time and energy.  You guys inspired me and I'm doing minimally 12,000 steps per day and most of the time around 16,000.  I feel great, my lymphedema is under control and I'm coming up on my 2nd 6 month mammogram.  Here in the States they do them every 6 months for 3 years and then once a year for the next 7 years.  After that I think they go to once every three years.  Every single test that they've done on me since this whole journey began has come back with flying colors.  And as a military veteran they've gone far above and beyond what I thought they'd test.  Bone scans, CAT scans, thyroid, heart, insulin checks, labs for everything in the world and apparently I'm healthy as a horse right now.  The Letrozole is the only tiny fly in the ointment and I'm getting achy hands and dry skin from it.  Small price to pay for being cancer free though.  So that's my update.  Please keep up your wonderful encouragement to everyone.  I have no idea how I would have coped without every one of you!  Hugs and love to you all!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hey there Leolady56  My skin has thinned from lack of estrogen and though my hands aren't peeling like yours, my nails have turned into a train wreck.  They bend and break and look like onions peeling.  Eucerin seems to be the best cream for me, though we're all different.  I've found that creams are far better than lotions.  And the thicker the cream the better results I get.  LOL  I understand about the 400 mg of Ibuprofen in the mornings helping, though my "go to" is Naproxen.  We all just have to find what works for us and then proceed with our heads held high.  I march around my pond singing "I Am Woman" by Helen Reddy, I will Survive or Roar by Katie Perry.  I'm sure my neighbors think I'm an eccentric, but who cares??   It's so good to talk to you guys again!  I have my Onco follow up next week as well as a Physical Therapy reevaluation.  I'm sure all is excellent. When is your birthday?  I'm horrid with dates, but will try mightily to wish you a blessed day at the proper time, but if I miss it, here's an early HAPPY BIRTHDAY!  Hugs to you!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi yellowroses I too make note of the Letrozole posts.  This particular brand is produced by Breckenridge.  Thus far I don't seem to be having too many problems with it.  Of course tonight I'm so tired I wouldn't know if I was having issues.  We got most of the plants and outside stuff moved today.  Walked over 5 miles lugging heavy boxes and stuff.  Whew.  Another day of it tomorrow.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies!  I'm not gone permanently, but the official move has started!  Yesterday did 19,000 steps, so that's going to count for my walking, although it wasn't a dedicated walk.  More like stops and start and high speed!  You guys are amazing!  One day I'll figure out how to pull a pic off my phone.  Saw a monster sized crane on our dock this morning.  Wow.  And hawks flying very close by.   Leo Lady sometimes the best laid plan go astray!  At least you had fun with your friends! mrsox Your little old lady feeder is surely trying to be sweet, so maybe if you mime what you're saying while you tell he it makes him sick she'll get it??   I'm going to have to say adieu for a couple of more days till we get internet down there.  Hugs to you all!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Good Afternoon lovely ladies:  I've been off for a while.  The move has taken a huge toll on me.  Sheesh, I even ran into a tree whilst mowing.  Of course I banged up the affected breast.  Just too much to do and pushing to get it all done.  So far today I've done 6.5 miles and this is part of what I did:https://photos.google.com/photo/AF1QipM_gykwIyrnDasWJx45G2llSVdPJbjpsXp4H492 It's just not uploading, but if you're interested you can take a peek.  Beautiful white heron beside our pond.  Mowing 1.25 acres is more than enough exercise for me today.  Hugs to you all!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Good Morning Everyone!  I haven't been on here much of late, but it's for a good reason.  I've gotten myself so busy I don't have time to take 2 deep breaths most days.  I see lots of new names here and my heart goes out to you.  BC is a real life changer in so many ways, but it can be beaten.  I had 2 lumpectomies with sentinel node biopsy done, no chemo, RT and then developed mild lymphedema.  It seemed every single day of my life centered around BC.  Now it's almost 2 years later and even though they won't officially tell me I'm cured, I'm sure I am.  No issues on anything since RT completed.  You all inspired me to walk a lot and I usually get between 15K - 25K per day.  I'm doing core building, Tai Chi, yoga and about to start Zumba.  I've lost 30 lbs and feel better than I've felt in years.  So if you're new here, rely on these ladies for encouragement and never, ever give up hope.  I'm hoping I can attach the lovely stork I saw out by our pond this morning.    Be blessed ladies!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: This is the road behind our new house.  I hit 20,000 steps the other day, but with all the property to check I'm managing at least 12,000-17,000 per day.  I like that the road appears to lead back into the light.  Hugs to all!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Thank you!  I've got to brag on this one thing.  Cholesterol levels of the majority of people here in the States tend to run somewhat high.  Some are way high.  Normal is 140-200.  Over 200 they want you on a cholesterol lowering med.  Hah.  Mine is 135 with is more than excellent.  This cancer hasn't been fun, but it's sure brought me lots and lots of other blessings in the form of dreams come true, better overall health and learning to eat balanced meals and portions.  And they say you can't teach an old dog new tricks!  Hugs!  Mira
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Penthelen:  Glad I gave you a little laugh.  You learn to cherish the moments that come upon you unexpectedly and make you giggle or be filled with joy at something beautiful.  I promise you this all gets better and when you're fit again, you can reschedule your Florida vacation.  Just don't come in July or August.  You'd melt.  95+ temps with a humidity level of 90% as well.  It's about like walking into an outdoor sauna.  October - March are the best times.  If you just have RT, you might still be able to make the trip in March.  RT tires you more than anything else, but lots of water helps.  I was getting back my energy in about 2 weeks.  Wishes for you to have the very best luck!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Waiting for results is the worst

Posts.Content: Hi Pixie!  I too am having issues with my neck and shoulder, but am not sure it's totally related to the effects of RT.  One thing that has helped me is two pillows.  One I put under my shoulder/back area and it overlaps the one that goes under my head.  That way when I'm sleeping my head isn't tilted at such an extreme angle and I feel a whole lot less stress the next morning.  Can't hurt to give it a try!  Mira
Posts.Title: Shoulder/neck pain 2 months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: You're quite welcome!  At least for me it seems that I'm tending to sleep in somewhat awkward angles in order to protect my much abused breast.  My very fluffy pillow had my neck at almost a 45 degree angle.  Too much strain for the night.  If it doesn't seem to help you might add a muscle rub ointment and if you still don't get relief, I think I'd be asking questions of your BC team.  Sweet dreams tonight!  Mira
Posts.Title: Shoulder/neck pain 2 months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hey Penny:  Where were you going to go in Florida.  That's where I live - but in the northern portion of the state.  You picked a good time to miss it.  It's getting really cold right now.  Give it a week or two and we'll be back to basking!  Now see?  There's a reason for your delay!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Waiting for results is the worst

Posts.Content: Hey Penthehen:  Just to let you know you're certainly not alone in not being familiar with all the terminology and abbreviations  At least you speak the same language!  Not that my American is much different, but we do use different terminology sometimes.  It can be confusing!  Don't you just wish you'd never had to even think about all this stuff??  Oh well.  We shall prevail and come out stronger.  Do the ROAR by Katie Perry!   xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Waiting for results is the worst

Posts.Content: Hi Stevie Q: I asked a similar question about a week ago and had some great answers.  I think the bottom line is you.  Apparently differing brands have different effects on each individual.  I'm at the 2 week point in taking Femara and have no side effects at all.  And I'm very, very grateful for that.  If you're only getting a little stiffness in the joints of your hand I think you may be pretty lucky as well.  The only supplement I'm taking is Glucosamine with Chondroitin which I have been taking for years.  It does help arthritic feelings, so you might consider it.  I'd check with your health care team before adding anything, but my team gave me a thumbs up.  One gal told me she had a short bout of dizziness at the 30 day point, but that it passed and she's having no side effects at all now.  Others have said that they had to experiment with different brands because the side effects were so severe.  Not sure I gave you a good answer or not, but the bottom line is listen to your body.  I hope we both stay fortunate!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Letrozole - side effects and supplements

Posts.Content: This is for any of you hating life on Letrozole:  The stuff works.  It does it's job and it's truly wonderful at it.  The pharmacies can rant all they want that there's no difference and pawn off the generics on us, but there ARE differences.  We're all uniquely and wonderfully made and we all react differently to various things.  Here in the States I haven't seen the generics you guys speak of, but I have my own issues with generics.  They arbitrarily switched me from Femara (which I did extremely well with) to AvKare and boy did I go down hill quickly.  I'm now on the Breckenridge brand and aside from a bit of tiredness am doing almost as well as with the Femara.   My point is this:  The pharmacies are trying to save money.  I get that part.  BUT they need to work with us to help us each find a generic that doesn't make our lives sheer misery.  My Oncologist said it well, "They're trying to save money which is fine,  but they don't see the patient and their misery.  They only see the money."  So hang in there and if one brand makes you feel poorly, BEG for another type.  Good luck!  Mira
Posts.Title: Letrozole - side effects and supplements

Posts.Content: Hi Kareelizabeth: As others have said, there are lots of conditions that can instigate a recall and re-check.  Over 15 years ago I had the same thing happen to me, and I had a biopsy done afterwards.  It was nothing.  Just some calcification's.  They put a marker in (painless) and that was the end of it.  Well for then it was the end.  After I went through menopause I didn't feel the pressure to get annual mammograms and foolishly missed quite a few years.  And here I am today.  Keep up with those mammograms and keep yourself well informed.  Yes, the waiting is the pits.  Getting on with the whole thing is a relief.  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Mammogram recall

Posts.Content: That's wonderful news!  Time to do a happy dance!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Mammogram recall

Posts.Content: Awww Batfinkcaz, your post broke my heart.  Everyone else has said all that I'd like to say to you, so won't re-post it, but will add a gentle hug to go with all the other lovely sentiments.  I've never liked roller coasters anyhow, but this emotional one is truly the pits!  Hugs Sweet Lady.  Mira
Posts.Title: New year, feeling blue

Posts.Content: Hiya Hides:  Be careful.  Lymph treatment is not strokes.  It's skin movement mostly.  Get it done once before you jump into it.  I use the Klose system which you can look up on YouTube.  Good luck and let us know how you fare!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Swollen wrist

Posts.Content: Good Morning Hides: I'd call your BCN and get it checked.  It could be a lot of things -lymphedema included and you don't want to be doing the wrong thing for what ever it is.  IF it's lymphedema, the massages you'll be doing aren't normal massage motions.  They're extremely light and move in a specific direction.  Your lymph system is divided into 2 parts.  The superficial one and the deep one.  The superficial one lies just beneath the skin and after lymph clearance doesn't have the ability to flow anymore.  Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD) employs a very soft almost pumping motion like a heart beat to get the lymph to move and recirculate to the deeper lymphatic system in the trunk.  But, as I said, it could be lots of things.  Time to pick up the phone!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Swollen wrist

Posts.Content: Hi Hides:  Yes, I have very mild lymphedema.  I didn't have full node clearance, just 3 nodes (which were all clear).  I had no idea I had it till they sent me to Physical Therapy for "treatment".  Mine was mostly in the elbow area and the breast.  But as I said it's very mild and they're treating it aggressively.  I use the Klose method and I think you can find it on YouTube.  I really like the way the instructor explains the massage movements.  She calls it a "stationary circle" .  You're really only slightly stretching the skin and letting it go back to rest.  It's nearly the exact same thing my physical therapist does when she does Manual Lymph Drainage on me.  Isn't the internet fabulous?  Can you imagine going through this rubbish all alone and thinking you're a nut case at times?   Please keep in touch.  I'll be thinking of you and really hope you can get seen before Christmas.  The sooner you tend to it the better off you are.  Oh yes.  I slept  on my side with a pillow on the "up" side and my arm elevated on the pillow for about 3 months.  I don't have to do that so much anymore.  I also wear a "swell spot" in my bra at night for the breast lymphedema.  Hugs to you!  Mira
Posts.Title: Swollen wrist

Posts.Content: Good Morning Hides!  Good and bad news from you this morning.  I'm delighted that you got in to see a lymphedema specialist and are on top of this early.  Don't be discouraged that you have it.  Yes, it can become a chronic condition, but also if treated early and vigorously can also more or less be in "remission" most of the time.  I think (and I may be wrong) that once you have it, you're always going to have it, but it may be a-symptomatic for a long time until you over stress the area and then it tends to flare up. I did wear a sleeve every day for about 2 months.  I don't need it now.  I do wear compression bras every day and do manual lymph drainage nearly every day.  They're not so bad, especially if they're fitted properly - and most of them have a "pocket" in them if you're in need of a prosthesis.  To be honest I hadn't even considered a prosthesis until after my last Physical Therapy and my PT put Kinesio tape on my breast.  That was a WOW!  I guess there was so much lymph pooled in there, that when it drained off, the breast literally shriveled down 2 full sizes!  I've gotten 3 bras so far.   Two are Amoena sports bras and the other is a Bellisse compression vest.  The Bellisse I only wear at home.  It's quite cumbersome feeling but the other two are very comfy.  I'm allowed to get 3 more after February and the fitter told me I should get one of their "pretty" bras for dressing up.  I like that idea! As far as the infection brewing, I'm sure your antibiotics will get that nasty little surprise under control quickly and am so very glad you listened to us on here and got the the Doctor before the holidays.  Good Job!  As with all things, knowing and knowledge gives you power over the unexpected surprises we're constantly getting from this horrid disease.   I hope you had a wonderful holiday season and are feeling more comfortable now.  Keep that arm elevated and please do look up some lymph drainage stuff on YouTube!  Even if you don't start the massage, it will give you a better idea of what to expect.   Please keep us posted!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Swollen wrist

Posts.Content: Millie, I have no idea, but am waiting to hear what others say.  I think you're doing all the right things to investigate it anyhow!  Mira
Posts.Title: red breast came on suddenly 18mths after radiotherapy?

Posts.Content: Hi Sparkler64: I'd get it checked just to make sure all is well.  After RT the tissues start to heal and harden.  I had basically the same thing done that you've had done and see a Physical Therapist once a month for Manual Lymph Drainage and scar shredding.  As the tissues harden they can bruise healthier tissues sometimes.  You could have a few broken capillaries from that, but I'd still get someone to LOOK.  I wouldn't just tell them about it, get them to do an exam.  You'll rest easier with professional opinions to support you.   Are you still doing the creams and massage?  They also help to expedite healing, but don't get too enthusiastic about it.  The skin is very fragile now.   Hope that was a bit helpful.  Mira
Posts.Title: Bruises started to appear under arms

Posts.Content: Oh Mam to 3:  I'm so sorry to hear of your diagnosis.  I know this is a frightening time for you and no amount of telling you that you're going to be OK is going to help a lot.  I think the plan that they'll set for you is going to depend on your HER status.  Once you get moving on it you'll start to feel a little more settled.  It's wonderful for you that you seem to be moving towards treatment very rapidly.  The quicker the better in my opinion.  I think the times of waiting are the worst.  So post away and someone who touches your heart and fears will come alongside to walk this path with you.  Sending you a very gentle hug from across the pond.  Mira
Posts.Title: Update after biopsy results today

Posts.Content: Hi Winky:  It's been a while since I've been on here too.  In re: Letrozole, I think perhaps a couple of months with one brand might help unless it's just horrible.  I'm in the States and they started me off on Femara and I had NO side effects.  I took that for 90 days and they switched me to AvKare.  Talk about horrible.  I was basically non functioning, couldn't wake up, hurt all over and was in a horrible mood most of the time.  The pharmacy reluctantly switched me back to Femara for one month, and then they sent me a Breckenridge brand.  To be truthful I was very leery of them, but really didn't have a whole lot of choice in the matter.  I started them, and though they're not as side effect free as the Femara, they're tolerable.  Yes, I get achy hands, but keep trying to move and stay at or above 10000 steps per day and it helps.  Lots of water seems to help too.  It's not all good news, but it's not all bad news either.  Hugs to you, Mira
Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: Good Morning ladies: Let me first say that I've benefited from this group immensely.  Everyone has such great information, compassion and encouraging spirits, that it's simply lifted me up when I've been feeling a bit sorry for myself or getting discouraged.  So I thank you from the bottom of my heart for that.  When I joined this group I didn't realize that it was a group for the UK at first.  I'm in the States.  I don't know if perhaps some of our terminology may differ for procedures - like is radiotherapy the same thing as radiation?, and other small things, but my question to you this morning is, "Do you think it would behoove me to join a group here in the States instead of this one?"  Gosh, I feel like I've gotten to know some of you and would hate to leave, but don't want to intrude either.  And perhaps some of the conversations would be clearer to me if we were using the same terminology.  Not sure.  I do appreciate all of you though.   And by the way, my infection has cleared up dramatically, I'm due to see the surgeon again on Wednesday and hopefully schedule the next lumpectomy recision.  My margins weren't clear.  After healing from that I'm supposed to start Letrozole and radiation.  Hugs to all!!!
Posts.Title: Should I find another group?

Posts.Content: Thank you to all of you who responded.  I have benefited from this group immensely, and really didn't want to leave it, but as I said I didn't want to be intrusive either.  It's good to know that being intrusive isn't an issue at all.  I loved the comments about learning from each other - and also the willingness to share on differing terminology.  You guys are wonderful!  Tomorrow I leave early in the morning to head to see my surgeon again.  I'm really hoping he sets the date for my next surgery.  This has been a very long 6 weeks of healing from the first surgery.  First the margins weren't clear, then infection set in, the surgeon drained me once,but the infection raged on.  Finally he cut the incision wide open so that it could heal from the inside out.  It's gone from a 5" x 3" raw open wound that I've had to wash and pack with gauze twice daily to perhaps a 2" x 1" open wound and not nearly so deep.  I'm dreading the next healing stage before I can move on to the radiation and letrozole.  But a concrete timeline for this part will at least give me something to focus on.  Another question.  Should he perhaps have put drains in after the first surgery?  He's a minimally invasive surgeon, so I'm thinking perhaps that's the reason he may not have opted to do that.  Should I ask about drains for this next surgery? Thanks for listening.  XXOO Mirabo
Posts.Title: Should I find another group?

Posts.Content: Thank you toxophilite!  I must say I would miss this lovely group, so am glad it's not an issue.  Hugs, Mirabo
Posts.Title: Should I find another group?

Posts.Content: Hi there soveryscared:  I'm in Florida and not too close to you, but our health care systems have to be similar.  If you're still frightened, get a second opinion.  Actually, if I didn't have great confidence in my health care system, I'd have opted for the University of Florida Health Care Systems.  Top notch!  You went to the University of Michigan Health Care Systems  and they too are top notch.  I would have a high degree of confidence if they told you it's not a worry, but if you need reassurance please see a different Doctor.  I did my radiation with the University of Florida Health Care Systems, and the Nurse Practitioner there was very, very well trained.  If she told me it wasn't an issue, I'd accept that.   Carolyn is right.  You need to calm down.  You don't need to make yourself sick over this.  Get another opinion and then trust them.  You're a bit young to be getting breast cancer, but it's certainly not impossible.  I found mine by accident and it was a fairly painless lump that felt rather numb.  No pink marks or blisters.  Other people have different outward symptoms and some people have no outward symptoms at all.  You said your NP told you it could be a macule.  If it's rather flat and not raised up that's certainly a possibility.  But the best part is that it's unremarkable enough for them to call it benign.  If you choose to get a 2nd opinion, you might start with your gynecologist and then move on to a dermatologist.   My hope is that you'll be less frightened and get a plan to help you deal with what ever is cropping up.  Keep in mind that if you're having a dermatological issue, your NP from the breast clinic may not be well versed in what she's seeing.  My Physical Therapist Doctor told me flat out that she wasn't good with derma issues and referred me on.  Last thing I want to add is that even if you have developed BC, it's become very, very treatable.  So follow up, get a 2nd opinion and then revamp.  If you need us we're here to listen.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Please help I am so scared

Posts.Content: I think it sounds like a very good plan if you've calmed down some.  If you're still worried about it then I'd suggest getting a dermatologist to take a peek.  It can't hurt anything to have it looked at and ease of mind is priceless!  An FYI here:  You found the best site in the world for support if you need it.  I was simply touched and amazed at the big hearts the ladies have on here.  Good luck!  Mira
Posts.Title: Please help I am so scared

Posts.Title: Please help I am so scared

Posts.Content: Hi TIA:  Mine was not found early on and by the time I noticed it, it was smooth a rather large lump and almost numb unless you pressed down on it fairly hard.  Chances are really good you have a cyst but if it turns out other wise, just remember it's treatable and we're all here for you.  The ladies (and men) on here are absolutely wonderful at holding your hand and walking alongside you if you need to make this journey.  You would get so much support to make everything easier.  However, until you know for sure, I'm sending you a hug and lots of good wishes.  Mira
Posts.Title: What did your lump feel like?

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic:  I'm so sad that you're going through all these negative emotions, but understand them to an extent.  I've had a few days of real crying jags and feeling depressed, but mostly I'm just irritated at all the waiting.  Dang.  It puts your life on hold for the longest time and I'm ready to move on!  Can't do a thing till my RT is done though.   It sounds like you're taking the right steps and you've already had some lovely replies with good advice.  I really have nothing to add to what's already been said, but wanted to pop on to tell you that you really are not alone with your feelings.  They're normal and OK and will pass eventually.  So just vent away!  xxoo Mira

Posts.Title: Big op tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Hi Jo!  Congratulations!  You are such a trooper and one day I'll be where you are!  It's so lovely to see successes and celebrate with others!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Last Herceptin done! thank you

Posts.Content: Hi Shepherdess:  I tried to answer you yesterday, but for some reason couldn't get logged on to the site.  Anyhow, I too have a severe needle phobia.  It may not be as bad as yours, but it's there.  I shake so badly my veins leak at the site of the needle insertion.  Well, I used to.  I've found that telling your team that you're terrified of needles and that you can't look helps.  I also tell them that they need to warn me immediately prior to the stick so that I don't jump.  99% of them do just as I ask and though it's not pleasant by any means, I can get through it.  Numbing may help some, but I think that we can pull up strengths that we never knew we had.  I'm so glad I had a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy.  That little needle is nothing compared to the cancer!  I did have the marker and they numbed the area first, I didn't look and they pre-warned before the stick.  Now it's done.  Best of luck to you!!
Posts.Title: Scared of needles

Posts.Content: Hi basonk: I relate to your frustration.  I too can wrap my head around what I have to do if I'm pre-warned, but unfortunately all cancer is very unique to the individual and until all the tests are done your team can't give you every answer.  Know that you still have choices.  I had my mind set that I would have surgery, no chemo, and radiation and be done by August 1st.  Hah.  It's now the end of September and I'm finally on 16/19 RT treatments.  I hate not knowing then when, why, how and where each day will bring, but I'm finally arriving at re-claiming my own life (my new life and at least to a degree).  My Oncologist ordered the Oncotype test at the time of the 2nd surgery so I didn't have to wait quite so long for the news as you're having to wait, but keep it in your mind that you can still choose.  They can recommend, and you do need to listen to them, but it's still your choice.  My Oncologist and I decided that if my Oncotype came back either as low or moderate chance of re-occurrence that I would NOT do chemo.  If it came back high I would.  I thought to have that finalized in my visit with her early August, but the results weren't back.  I simply melted into a pool or whimpering terror.  The unknown is so hard to tolerate.  Luckily, the results came back the same day of my appointment, but after I'd left.  Bless her heart, she called me immediately to let me know the good news and I did NOT have to have chemo.   I didn't like not being fore warned about the possibility of chemo when I thought it was off the table, but on the other hand, I don't think I would have  found quite the degree of peace about things that I was able to achieve from time to time.  You've got some very uncertain times ahead of you in various ways, but you'll do it.  I'm so looking forward to Monday and ringing the bell in the UF Health Institute.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Thought I knew my treatment plan until today

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlettem:   I'm thinking of the things I want to say to you and discarding them one by one because they may or may not be true to your situation.  The ones I can share with you that are certain are 1.  You have my deep sympathy that you're faced with this situation.  2. You've found the best site possible to help you through this.  I live in the States and I'm in various groups here, but this particular site has been my salvation.  People always reply to you.  It has great information and I just can't say enough good things.  These ladies are fabulous!  3.  You're going to have lots of roller coaster days with your emotions all over the place and this is a great place to let it out.  You're never alone.  4.  I think that waiting is the hardest.  When you have a concrete plan and time line on the board, you can just "get on with it".  Not knowing and waiting to hear the news is just plain hard.  No doubt you'll find someone on here with a very similar situation to yours and perhaps even be walking a similar timeline.  I found several and they were such rocks when I needed to lean.  Do let us know what the results session tells you.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today with Breast Cancer at 31

Posts.Content: Hi 3301apk: I don't know this for sure, but I would think the Demi-permanent colors would be OK.  Redken International makes some lovely ones.  They only coat the outside of the cuticle and don't make any permanent changes.  Usually last 8-10 shampoos.  pH is 4.5 so they're well within normal limits for natural hair.  I use them periodically going 2 shades lighter than my natural color and it looks pretty much like highlights in my hair.  Mira
Posts.Title: Colouring hair post chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Tigg: Honey, you're just barely post surgery.  Yes you're going to be tired.  You didn't mention chemo, so I'm assuming you were able to dodge that bit?  RT will make you more tired.  Please join the January Radiotherapy thread and read the recommendations.  Even if you don't start till February you can start prepping yourself.  Lots of water and TLC!   Your mum is a very wise woman.  Problems shared are much, much lighter than carrying the burden alone.   Sending a big gentle hug to you!  Mira
Posts.Title: Fatigue.

Posts.Content: Hi Superskydiver: I'm not trying to alarm you but your description sounded like what I experienced.  I had developed a post operative infection and was unaware of what was going on.  My breast burned like fire and the only thing that eased it for a little while was ice packs.  I'm really glad you're seeing your Doctor in a few days.  Here's hoping that it's just post operative discomfort!  Mira

Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: Hi Shirl3:  I can see everyone is a bit different.  I have very dense breast material and having no support was horrible for me.  So the button downs were pretty much out.  I found some nursing nightgowns that provided just a small amount of support and that was enough for me.  The nice part about them is that I could step into them and they didn't have to go over my head.  They were soft, cuddly and had built in bras.  My lump was a 2:00 so position might make a difference.  And one more piece of information.  My node incision never ever gave me a whit of problems.  It healed more quickly than the breast incision and never hurt a bit.  My advice is to try various things and use what ever feels best to you.  xx Mira
Posts.Title: What to wear after a lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi All:  I have mild lymphedema after WLE and SLN removal.  The lymphedema is very mild, slightly in my elbow area, but more on the affected (left) breast.  Yesterday my Physical Therapist did Kinesio taping on my breast.  It's the darndest thing I've ever seen.  It looks like they made a fat fish design on me with this crazy tape.  Anyhow, wondering if anyone else has had this done, and did it really help?  I live in FL in the States and it's hot here most of the time.  Hence, lots of sweating.  I can't see this stuff staying on more than perhaps a day.  Nor can I moisturize with it.  I'm going to try to be good for a couple of days, but unless someone here has had a really good outcome from the taping I think I'm going to tell her to not do it again.  I sure can't feel it working, and right now I feel like a faded advertisement for sloppy tattooing.  Eww.  Would welcome any and all feedback!  Mira
Posts.Title: Kinesio Taping - request for information

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone!  I'll leave it on till it starts to peel up (the sternum area is already super loose) and see what it does.  Jmp, I have no idea how to tag people  I've tried that multiple times and never been successful.  If you figure it out, let me know!  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Kinesio Taping - request for information

Posts.Content: London Lass you're too funny!  All good information, but yours made made me laugh like a loon.  I got this hilarious picture in my head of being carted off to the booby hatch for an exposed boob.  Ignore me.  I get silly sometimes.  Guess I'll be sticking to the refrigerated Aloe and the box fan in my bedroom.  Also glad I waited to give the temptingly cold pads a try.  Actually, I'm not all that red.  The main thing that's a bit sore is the tip of the nipple.  Extra Aloe there!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Ice and RT?

Posts.Content: Hi Julia!  Thanks so much for that great input!  OK I'll "stick" with it.  Aren't you just too punny!  I'm doing the compression bra thing as well as the tape.  The bras I was able to find are really quite lovely, so I don't mind them a bit.  My PT told me she'd teach me how to put the tape on next time I see her if it seemed to help.  To be perfectly honest, the breast feels much, much softer today.  I really appreciate your feedback!  xxoo Mira This is an addendum to the above message.  I just went in to change into the nightie and that stuff works!  The left breast is now considerably smaller than the right one - and it should be after two WLE with a 4 CM tumor.  Wow.

Posts.Title: complications following LD back muscle op

Posts.Content: Hi Anni:  No question is silly first of all.  I think it may depend on the hospital doing the treatment.  I'm in the States so it could be quite different, but they did not want shoes on while on the bed.  However, they did allow me to wear yoga pants so I didn't have to remove them.  They also offered me sheets to help me keep warm as it was indeed very cold in there.  With my yoga pants I didn't need the sheet though.  I had the most wonderful RT team!  Don't forget to drink lots of water!  Mira
Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: Hi Stevie Q:  I too am taking Letrozole since June and will be going for my bone scan this coming Friday.  To be honest I'll be very surprised if I have any type of Osteoporosis, but one never knows.  The lack of Estrogen does tend to leech the calcium out of your bones.  I had a bone scan done in 2015 just because my Dr. at the time wanted to check and at that point he told me my bones were so healthy that I'd probably never need another.  Of course the was Pre-BC and Pre-Letrozole, so now I get another bone scan.  Just to be sure there was no bone weakening, my Dr. put me on calcium and vitamin D and highly encouraged me to drink a lot of Almond Milk as it's protein instead of Dairy.  If you're hurting from the Letrozole, you might consider trying a different brand.  I take the Femara brand and have no side effects from it.  I've heard some very bad stories from other ladies on the generics.  Hope that was helpful!  Mira
Posts.Title: Letrozole/bone scan and Osteoporosis

Posts.Content: Hi Jinky!  Welcome to this warm and loving community.  I too am in the States, but in FL and when I was diagnosed last April I looked high and low for a place that would inform, support and encourage.  All the medical advances we have here don't begin to compare to the plain old love and compassion I've found on this site.  So welcome!  It's a rough journey we're all on, but one day at a time we can do it.  You've had one heck of a hard ride this past year,  You're an incredibly strong woman.  Your friends gave you good advice about staying upbeat and resting, but I know from personal experience that it's not always possible.  Sometimes hubby would put on Katie Perry's Roar for me and it helped.  Prayer helps a lot too.  Now I'm going all retro and doing Helen Reddy's I Am Woman.  Just had my first mammo post cancer and didn't have to do an ultra sound, so I think it's good.  I'll find out later this week when I see the GP.  You're on the last big leg of your treatment with the RT.  Keep drinking lots of fuid (at least 2 liters a day) and moisturize, moisturize, moisturize!  You're almost there!  I hope they have a bell for you to ring post RT.  It's not just for you - it gives all the patients great hope and joy.  Best wishes to you!  And a gentle hug.  Mira
Posts.Title: New here

Posts.Content: YES!!  Although I didn't realize what was happening at the time, my energy levels had bottomed out.  I was gulping down at least 1000 mg of caffeine a day just to function.  And frustrated with myself fro my lack of energy.  I took an early retirement 3 years ago, had a year off and then the dreaded diagnosis.  I'm so grateful that I retired when I did as I was a high school teacher working with 300 girls.  Even though I wasn't physically with them anymore, there were many who were simply devastated when they heard of my diagnosis.  Neither they or I needed to go through this if I was still working.  One other thing I noticed was weight gain.  Maybe 10-20 lbs and my breasts kept getting bigger and bigger till I was up to a 38D (Normally 36B).  I'm only 3 months out from RT now, and still don't have all my energy back, but it's coming.  I've lost 23 lbs and am up to 4 miles per day.  Whew.  What a ride.  Mira
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hey Susan:  Sounds very much like my life from across the pond.  (I'm in Florida).  It's perfectly amazing to me how our bodies send us messages that we don't always know how to interpret.  My diagnosis also hit when I was 65.  In fact, they called me with the results on my birthday last April.  This past year has been pretty difficult on a personal level, but a piece of cake compared to what some of the other ladies go through.  It's all relative though isn't it?  For me it's been a rough year.  I finished RT in October and am on Letrozole, but really ready to move on.  We too are packing up and getting ready to move.  Out of the city into a small rural town.  So this will be a new and much better year for us both!  Thanks for the post!  xxoo Mira
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi Solow:  You've sure come to the right place to get comfort and encouragement.  We've all experienced the same low, low state that you're currently experiencing.  Busy is the key till you know what's what.  You'll go up and down in your emotions and then suddenly it seems like you'll have it all straight in your head and something may change.  It's indeed a roller coaster, and the ride isn't fun, but you can do this.  If you need a shoulder, there are many people on here that are walking a very close path to yours.  I finished my surgeries in July, did my RT and am out the other side now.  Still having some issues with the Letrozole, but doing pretty darn good over all.   You're going to feel much more settled and ready to take on this battle once you know what direction you need to go.  For now, know that it's perfectly normal to be feeling out of control and fearful.  My heart goes out to you, this is one of the hardest times of the whole journey.  We're all here if you need us.  Hugs, Mira
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info!  I'm really lucky to be on the Femara brand.  My Oncologist went to bat for me with the pharmacy and I'm forever in her debt on that one!  I had read that Sandoz was created after the patent on Femars expired and the ingredients are almost identical.  It's excellent information for those who are experiencing Letrozole issues.  I know for the 2 weeks I was on generics I turned into a basket case.  If I had started out on the generics and didn't know how painless the Femara was for me, I may have opted to just take my chances.  So double thanks for this post!  Hope it helps someone else who is having Letrozole issues.  xxoo Mira

Posts.Content: Hi Boobylou!  I'm so happy you're having no issues!  I didn't either till they put me on this crazy generic one from AcKare.  What a nightmare!  I'm kind of glad I experienced it so that I can really relate  to those who are having issues, but sooooo glad my Oncologist told me to stop them immediately too.  She's going to try to get me back on the Femara exclusively, and if she can't she's going to recommend Exemestane which is also an aromatase inhibitor.  Apparently, unlike Letrosole which is non-steroidal, this one is steroidal.  Initially that alarmed me a bit, but after reading some about it, it might actually be better.  Not done reading yet.  But anyhow, thank goodness I'm off the crud stuff for now.  I'll happily take the Femara, and will be willing to try a different generic, but the AcKare is OUT for me.  I'm not positive, but I think it may have been the titanium dioxide that they use for fillers that made me so poorly.  Thanks for the post!  xxoo Mira

Posts.Content: Hi HeliG I wrote my post quite some time ago and was still on Femara at that time.  I'm on another generic now.  It's the Breckenridge brand, and it's' not too bad.  I'm having some small issues with my hands, but nothing too bad.  The AvKare generic was horrible for me.  I did try to get the Sandoz brand, but had absolutely no luck on that.  I'm in the States and I get the idea that Sandoz United States doesn't really do much with Letrozole.  Anyhow, it's not available for me at all.  I really wish you luck in finding it as I've heard good things about it.  Barring that, if you really can't tolerate the other generic Letrozole, BEG your Dr. to put Brand Specific on your Rx for Femara.  xx Mira
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice

Posts.Content: Hi Emma!  I read your post and my heart went out to you.  I don't think your attitude is in the minority at all.  Mine was just about the same when I found a lump on my left breast.  My thoughts are with you as you go to get this investigated today and I'm hoping for very good news for you.  However, if it isn't good news I just want to give you a warning that all of the 2nd guessing you're doing right now is very likely going to continue as you journey down this path.  My surgery is done, I'm on Letrozole for at least 5 years,  I don't have chemo to do and I start radiation next week.  I think guessing what comes next, "What Iffing" and waiting was the hardest of the entire process for me.  Our brains frequently tend to inflate situations way beyond the reality.  So, take a deep breath and know you have lots of support.  Please let us know how it all sorts out!  Mira

Posts.Title: Test day today!

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies:  I need some help if any of you have the information.  I finished my RT after lumpectomy and started on Femara brand of Letrozole.  Absolutely no side effects.  For what ever reason when I got my refill they sent me a generic.  I went down to the pharmacist (before I started taking the generic) and thank goodness he was at least honest with me.  He said it was a price issue - and of course I already knew that the Femara costs more.  I thought my Oncologist had ordered only brand specific, but obviously she didn't.  The pharmacist told me that in order for them to change me back to the Femara 3 things have to happen.  1.  The Dr. needs to order brand specific (I see her on Wednesday so will ask her then 2.  The "committee" needs to meet and make an evaluation (this committee is from the pharmacy and any documentation about bad reactions should be submitted to them.  Which leads to #3.  If I go ahead and start taking the generic and have negative side effects it will help them to determine to keep me brand specific.  I started the new brand 2 weeks ago.  The first week I was very tired and headachey, but thought maybe I could handle them.  This week is horrible.  I feel like I have the flu and hurt from the top of my head to my ankles.   I've been looking and looking for information on here about the generics vs Femara and am coming up empty handed.  I know I've read it somewhere, but can't find any thing that's really concrete.  I'd love to be able to take that along with me to the Oncologist on Wednesday.  Anyone know where I can find it?  I tried the search bar on the top, but so far no luck.  Thank you so much, Mira
